ratings.comment: 343H with Burke was, by far, my favorite class this semester. Lectures were fascinating and useful. After taking this class you truly have a grasp on the material and gain a much better understanding of the material than those in the non-honors section. However, exams are quite difficult and require creative thinking. Take Burke if you can!

Burke is a brilliant chemist and fantastic lecturer. Manages to speak at slow paces while giving you tons of info in his lectures, all well explained. However, if you don't want to put a ton of work in/ care about your GPA dont do this class. Hardest exams ive ever taken and I breezed through chem 109,and 329 with way less effort.

A lot of the negative reviews seem to stem from students who did not perform as well in O-Chem as they might have liked. Burke's tests are extremely hard in comparison to other professors, and this is not helped by the fact the subject itself is difficult for many. That said, he's extremely passionate about the subject and a good instructor.
Good professor with difficult tests teaching a difficult subject. Clearly very knowledgeable in is field and can always offer an excessively satisfying response to student questions.

I had Burke for 343H/345H. He's an incredibly intelligent guy and gives clear and interesting lectures. Material and tests are very challenging, but it's appropriate for an honors level class, especially if you put in the work. Andrew the TA (who's also amazing) generally gives discussion quizzes 1-2 weeks before a midterm, so watch out for those.

Listening to Burke's lectures, reading the textbook, and taking the time to do a bit of memorization will be enough to get a firm grasp of the basics in the course. The tough part comes in with the tests- always a bit too long, and with some incredibly difficult questions. He makes up for this by setting an 80% as the threshold to get an A.

Prof. Burke really expects you to read the book and put in a lot of work outside of class--if you don't, you can get really behind in the lecture content. He sometimes tries to make it interesting and applies some concepts to real life, and he's a funny guy.

Organic chemistry is challenging and while Prof. Burke is incredibly intelligent, his tests were extremely hard. Expect to have to study a lot, and the molecules on the tests will be much more complex and difficult then any you will find in the textbook or in his lectures. The homework was not very helpful for exams.

Professor Burke is easily one of my favorite professors at UW-Madison. He spoke very clearly and would make sure his students understood the concepts. He added modern-day reactions and gave little history updates so we could understand the chemistry world. His exams were incredibly difficult but doable. Reading was a necessity. Would take it again.

Very intelligent guy. However, the subject matter is very difficult, and his exams are extremely difficult. His lectures are interesting and engaging and he seems to really care about teaching his students.

Burke was a crazy smart dude. I thought i'd hate his class but in the end I ended up liking him a bunch. He makes you really, really understand the material which is why everyone says he's so hard. If you like to memorize, good luck

His tests are extremely hard. Do not rely on the practices exam to determine whether or not you are ready for his tests because they are completely different. He gave exams as if we were an honors class.  also, don't rely on just remembering the material because you will not pass.

You can study for hours, days, weeks doesn't matter because chances are the exam will be stuff you've never seen before. Its curved, but if you are a learn by doing memorization take a different prof. In order to do well you need to be able to extrapolate what you learn in the extreme.

Your experience in this class will likely depend on the mercy he bestows on the exams. I had a very fair exam in this class and I've also had exams that might of well been written in latin. At any rate, its curved, its ochem. He's none the worse than any other prof out there. Good if you wish to have high understanding and like up to date material.

This is a tough class, and he expects you to learn a lot from the book. He then skims over the basics and go e specific detail in lecture. Though I did not enjoy the content, Burke is a genuinely nice guy and will help you if you ask.

Burke is hands down the worst professor I have had on campus. There have been multiple exam questions that included material that wasn't covered until several weeks after the exam. I got an A in 343 and have put in twice the amount of effort into his class and still struggle. Avoid Burke at all costs.

Do yourself a favor and avoid Burke like a plauge. I can't stress enough how difficult it is to succeed in his class. I've studied harder for this class than any other and I still came short. You basically walk into exams blind to what may be on it. He also mocks students for getting below what he expected the average to be. Take Bowman if possible

AVOID AT ALL COSTS: teaches with a cocky attitude and mocks students for asking questions. Often seems like he could care less about students. Tests are nothing like the practice exams and copied out of ancient text books. Lectures are irritatingly incomprehensible. Class averages on exams 50%. All around worst professor I've had at UW - Madison.

First review for a professor I have ever written because Burke was so bad. Flies through lectures missing steps and reactants. Mocks students and talks down to them when they ask questions. Practice tests don't resemble the actual exams at all. I worked really hard and hoping to pass. Do everything you can to take a different professor.
Burke sucks. I didn't learn anything from him the entire semester. It was very stressful and made me hate ochem.

All I can hope is he does curve or I might fail. My 343 professor had helpful notes and problem sets and I did great. Burke, contrarily, does not provide any of these. His exam is extremely tough and you basically have no idea in what way you could study for the exam to improve your grade. I would be so upset if he gives me the  first F in my life.

Prime example of an absolutely brilliant man who can't teach. His lectures go in no chronological order, you can't read his handwriting, & we literally had exam averages in the 40's. Offers helpful weekly problem sessions for extra practice. He teaches the class like it's honors when it's not. Genuinely nice guy though & can be hilarious

Avoid Burke. He is unapproachable, condescending, and not helpful. His tests are above and beyond anything taught in lecture. Learned everything from the book basically and expects you to use that as your main learning tool and not him. His handwriting is atrocious and he messes up structures frequently. I loved 343 and can't stand his class.

Lectures are disorganized and confusing. Claims exams are similar to given practice exams and book problems, but the exams couldn't possibly be more different. No problem sets provided, and he cant even type up his own exams. They are photocopied from something from the 80s and you can barely read some of it. I got an A in 343 and used to love it.

Only take Burke when you have solid ochem background. He won't teach you everything you need to know. You have to spend extra time studying to get good grades. Attending lecture is not enough; his lecture is very unorganized. Everyone hates Sapling Assignment; it's not useful for the exam

Burke does not understand the students at all. He assigns hw that covers material ahead of where he is in lecture, so you never learn anything because you get all the problems wrong and you're on to the next one by the time he gets to that material. Doesn't give practice problems and claims books problems are similar to tests but they're not

Burke does not teach. He is an awful professor that tells you read the book because "he is a guide, not a map." His exams are incredibly hard and nothing like the practice exams. Does not tell you what you need to know for exams so you basically just guess what you need to know. He does not show mechanisms for reactions. Exam averages were 50%

I don't get why he has such a high score. I had him for 343 and did everything to avoid getting him again but they switched professors last minute. His notes are super unclear and untidy, he leaves out steps in mechanisms and doesn't assign any practice problems that resemble exams. Likes to give tough exams to prove his point that O chem is hard

Burke is a great ochem professor! He really cares about the subject and about his students.  However, his tests are difficult. It's better to know concepts and not just memorize specific reactions. Also, he's pretty keen on intramolecular reactions. I liked how from the start he told us that an 80% was an A, no waiting for an unpredictable curve.

Prof. Burke has an amazing way of presenting material. He is well organized and is clear in his lectures. He records lectures which is great to go back and review from. Online problem sets are tedious so use the book problems he recommends. Tests are hard and rarely reflect the practice exam. He looks for overall understanding not memorization.

He is a very good professor, the lectures are very straight forward and helpful. He presents material from the book in a more distilled way, but I would say reading the subjects prior to attending lecture is very helpful. He offers weekly review sessions that are very helpful, and goes over problems. Exams require you to know literally everything.

Burke knows how to use the concepts behind the material to rigorously challenge and engage students.  Expects great things, but also strives to bring out your best.  Tests are like puzzles-- requiring massive synthesis of information, but fun ;)

Excellent. His lectures are engaging and he is clearly interested in his students' success. I have learned more in 2 months of his class than an entire year of Chem 115-6. Exams are not easy, but doable if you prepare appropriately and are prepared to think (not just memorize). My only criticism is that his handwriting isn't too good.

Burke is the best chem professor I've ever had. Lectures are run at a perfect pace for honors students. Tests can be very difficult, but if you do the practice exams and assignments, you should know exactly what to expect. You're not competing against your classmates for an A because the grading is out of total points. Take him if you can.

Burke is one of the best professors I've ever had. His lectures are clear and he's always willing to answer questions. He wants his students to succeed and learn organic chemistry. Some of his tests are beyond difficult but his curve is in the students' favor. His extra problem sessions are very helpful. He'll answer any question during them.

Tough class with a lot of material to cover. He does his best but gets off track and the lecture could be better organized. The tests are hard and are what makes up most of your grade. Nice guy with interesting/funny stories.

After 4 semesters of chemistry, Burke has been the best chemistry professor that I've had (by a long shot). Did a great job tying together concepts in lectures, but could have managed board space a little better. Exams were very well written - challenging, but doable.

Burke is an ok professor. He really knows the material but lectures can be very ambiguous and often are disorganized. However, he makes it entertaining with some really great stories. Exams were either really easy, or incredibly difficult.

One of the best professors I've had. Holds a 1.5 hr long review session every week and is more than willing to answer any question you have ad does not make you feel dumb for asking. You'll have to work hard but tests are extremely fair. He definitely wants people to do well. Take him if you can!! He also tells great stories.

Extremely smart guy but comes off as really arrogant. Hard exams, but he teaches at a high level as well. You will learn a lot from him. Not too hard to get a B, but getting an A is pretty rough (~79% in the class) especially with how hard the tests are. Tells you that you should study 3 hours a day for his class.
Great professor.  Very helpful and friendly.
He was a pretty good prof. I definitely learned a lot from him, but also was just overwhelmed with the subject. He was very approachable and answered questions very well

Dr. Burke is an incredible professor.  He really got me interested in chemistry again after a rough year in Chem 115/116.  His class is engaging and very doable.  Reading the book is highly recommended, but he also runs problem sessions each week for extra help.  The book is old, so you don't have to buy an expensive new version.

A really great professor. I left the class burnt out beyond belief, but I felt like I had learned the material completely and totally. Great book. He can be kind of awkward at times and likes to talk about himself and muse about life and science when one on one, but it's at least entertaining. Helpful, knowledgeable, friendly, highly recommended.

Professor Burke is probably the best professor i have ever had.  His knowledge of organic chemistry is mind blowing.  The class is very difficult but you learn a ton.  If you are interested in chemistry and are willing to work this class is well worth it.
Awesome, he keeps you on your toes with tangents that somehow always end up relevant (yes he can relate bonding to tying 2 cats by the tail and throwing them over a clothesline)

This was the hardest, most unclear class I have ever taken. You have to completely teach yourself the material, he teaches abstract ideas that arent tested and the tests are RIDICULOUS. Do not take honors unless you are a chem major and are taking less than 14 credits as it requires more than 20 hours a week of work. Good luck if you go for it.
Great educator, probably the smartest person I've ever talked to. Seems to genuinely care about students. Tests are fair. If you have the chance, take him over any other O-Chem lecturer.

Professor Burke is one of the true greats at this university. He is one of the most intelligent people you could ever have the opportunity to learn from during your undergrad career. He will challenge you though.
Very very difficult class.  Must must read the book and attend lecture.  Prof knows his stuff and is always willing to help.  Tests are tough, but grading reflects that it is an honors class.
